and as well as there being many different types of projects or many different ways of contributing
so you could be someone who's just contributing via creating issues or
reporting bugs you could submit pull requests or you could create a project and run a project i be a project
maintainer so my experiences are sort of gathered around based around
being a project maintainer of a large open source project by myself
so in this talk i'm gonna sort of walk through the history of jason.net and sort of talk about what i've learned

about writing html it was sort of designed back in 2000 2001 with the birth of
net so i could write the initial uh html no problem so the html was where i

but i needed a way to take all the values that i had set on the server and then send them to javascript so

i try to do everything manually within code i would check did someone
set whether there is an overlay displayed when the javascript dialogue is displayed and if yes then i wrote it
out is there a wood set if yes i'll write it out was there a height set if yes i'll write it out but it was all very verbose and manual and error-prone
and i wasn't very happy with it and i looked at that and i thought you know what i'm really doing is on the
server i'm setting some configuration and then i'm sending it to the client
what i really want to do is i want a data format that i can serialize all my data to
and then on the client i just read it so i did what any developer would have done back in 2006.
i used xml specifically i used xml serializer so it was super easy on the server one line
one line and you're done but i quickly discovered the xml it's a real pain in the ass to work with in
javascript first you need to load that entire string into a document which is
easier said than done because of all the different browsers and the way they do xml slightly differently
then you need to do stuff like document.getelementbyname and you give it overly visible when you check whether
that returned a result or not if it did then you give it elements and you'd extract the value from it
um and it was horrible and even a relatively experienced developer like me at the time could tell that this this
was wrong this wasn't the this wasn't the best approach so fortunately at the same time well
just after i discovered javascript object literals and suddenly the javascript was easy
so this is what i just wrote out to test it and it was easy because i was working literally with a normal javascript
object the parsing was done when that script tag was parsed and i didn't
really need to do anything i just had a javascript object ready to go but now i had a new problem that was creating the
javascript object literal i couldn't find any done libraries to do it so that was the beginning of json.net
so the first version was released back in june 2006 so just over 10 years
ago and every time i just well once i had finished writing it and
using it with my web dialogue i wrote a blog post i zipped up some
source code in a dll file and uploaded it to my blog and that was pretty much it now at the time jason was so new so
jason was also sort of defined as a standard back in 2006 by
douglas crockford that a lot of classes and jason.net didn't actually start with the word json
so if you're familiar with jsonconvert so jsongcovert.serialize object deserialize object and objects
like j object and jra they were originally javascript convert javascript array javascript object
and it wasn't until a couple of releases later when the terminology jason caught on that i
started renaming things and this photo it's of wellington so that's where i live
i'm guessing the fireworks are to celebrate guy fawkes and not the release of jason.net
so what i found with starting json.net is open source starts with solving a problem it starts with one or two
developers they've got a problem that they need to solve and they see the opportunity to solve it or
take something and do it better i mean it just so happens that along the way they take what they've done um in
their project and they just put it online i was talking with jeremy who wrote autopamper automapper
and he said that he wrote automapper just because he needed to use it at work and it wasn't until nine months later
that he just happened to turn it into a project and upload it to um github
and it's quite amazing how many similar popular donet projects started up in
this way so we've got n log and we've got n unit
mock and automatically and then json.net
so at this point you've got a library and maybe you've put it up
somewhere for people to use where do you go from there there are a couple of options you could
leave your blog post and github and have it on nougat and just allow developers to discover it organically or
maybe you could go out and proactively reach out to developers and let them know that you've create created
something that it exists and i think this reaching out to developers is something that we're not really familiar
with that it's reaches outside our comfort zone we're good at writing code we can write an open source library but
how do we get people to actually start using it so with json.net part of a reason i
released it as open source so i originally wrote it because i had a problem that i needed to solve part of the reason i released it was because i
had a brand new blog and i wanted content for my blog and i wanted to get traffic
so when i released jason.net i wrote a blog post and then i sort of submitted it to a number of news sites
so the one you can see here this is ajaxian so back in 2006 um
ajax was a big uh buzzword of the day and ajaxian was like the hub of tech for
some reason um so i submitted a blog post here and they republished it and i got uh quite a
few hits which was great so also fun fact
scott hanselman was the very first commenter of the very first blog post about jason.net and i'm pretty sure he
found his way to my blog probably by ajax in 14 minutes later he also then submitted
the first bug so thank you very much scott but he gave a lot of great detail you don't usually
get bug reports that detailed so what i found with reaching out to
developers is that that first blog post is quite important and what you want is you want something
that explains the problem that your project solves and how easy it is to use
and i think this is actually something i didn't do very well with json.net my first blog post was sort of more
technically focused on some low-level achievements so i wrote a ford only json reader and a ford only json writer that
were very memory efficient and that's sort of what i showed off on my blog but commenters would come along and i'd
look at that and say that's kind of hard to use i don't want to use that now that first release of json.net it
had a serializer like you could serialize things in just one line but i didn't show that off
um so i think nailing that first blog post is key and once you've done it once you can then
sort of reuse that content so if you ever in the future want to have a basic website you can just take
that initial description and re reuse it if you have documentation you can take those
basic quick start guides and reuse them so a good elevator pitch for your open
source project is always useful to have and if you really want to go a step
beyond you can create a screencast video so um
anthony and nick from the glimpse project there they made a screencast of showing off
glimpse and as you can see it ended up with over 40 000 views which is really quite remarkable and they created it a
lot with helping popularized glimpse in the beginning
so you've written on a blog post where can you submit it a jackson is not the tech powerhouse that it used to be
the first place is social media so you can tweet it and reddit's another place you can go
there's a couple of good subreddits you can look at the asp.net team and the
net team and microsoft also do their part to sort of evangelize
open source projects and blog posts that community members write
so the asp.net team has a weekly community stand-up video that they stream live and as part of it there's a
john galloway loves community section and he sort of will um sort of plug uh
open source um projects and blogs that have um contacted him throughout the throughout
the week i mean like likewise the net team they have a weekly blog post um with links to
donate related blog posts and they also um focus on nougat packages so one a week
they also focus on a xamarin game app once a week and also a unity game
and the final place i'd really recommend is stack overflow so stack overflow is the place people go when they've got a problem
and if you can get to sac overflow and find
people who have an issue that your open source project solves you can answer them you can show them
how it's done and then you can just link back to your your blog post or website or nuget
package or github and this is actually something i did quite a lot with json.net
back when stack overflow started up i would look through it occasionally and i'd
find questions from people who had issues that um perhaps javascript
serializer which is built into net or data contract json serializer also built into net if they had issues that those
libraries didn't solve i'd show them how json.net solved them i mean i'd link them back to
my website and some of those questions now have hundreds and hundreds of thousands of views so it's the sort of
thing which really pays off over time so i will share with you my number one
tip for getting developers attention so this is the one weird trick to make developers lose weight or
something so developers love performance
they love comparing performance i love talking about performance i love seeing performance improve
how often have you heard someone say you should try x i hear it's really fast
so what i've noticed over time so every every version of json.net well
not every version but most versions of json.net um i released i write a blog post and as part of that blog post i
quite often will sort of highlight some performance improvement i've made so in this release i did a couple of years ago
i really improved um how f-sharp discriminated unions uh serialized and deserialized i went from a whole bunch
of reflection happening every time to cache reflection and i've noticed that developers when
they see um blog posts that talk about performance they're much more highly upvoted
liked shared whatever um than other ones so i've noticed this so much that when i
sort of sat down and i decided to come up with like a tagline for jason.net so
like a short one-line um description so i built it straight into the description so jason.net is a popular
high performance json framework for net so if you're doing this
don't don't lie about performance so you want to keep performance in mind you want to work on it you want to be fast but don't lie about performance
don't be a dick and cook up scenarios where you win and your benchmark is the best and everyone else
um loses horribly and also don't obsess about being the
fastest there'll always be some library that will take what you've got and maybe they'll
move some perhaps useful feature and like suddenly they're faster and more benchmarks but maybe they're harder to
use like jason donate isn't the fastest serializer so there's a serializer
called jill jrl which is faster and it does that by using il emit
heavily which means pretty much whenever you want to serialize a type it uses ilemit
to pretty much generate a custom serializer on the fly that's tuned exactly for your type so it means
gel is faster but it also means because it uses ilmet it can't run everywhere
because ilmet isn't supported and ahead of time compilation
so yeah they're a pros of cons but my recommendation is always just think about performance and sort of highlight
it when talking about your library developers uh eat it up
so now i want to talk about motivation so what has motivated me to keep working on json.net
so at this point i had something which worked for me it solved my problem
i'd put it out there on my blog and my blog was getting lots of hits at this point i felt like i was done it was time
to walk away
so yeah it works for me i've got popular blog posts i was also when i started working on json.net i'd only finished
university like a year earlier um i only had one job ever so it was something to put on my resume
and this wasn't just something that i felt when people asked me i would say they would ask me what my plans were i
would say i was done so way back in 2006 this is an email conversation
between a couple of other people who wrote javascript
and jsonlibrariesand.net so ajax.net pro and jrock
this will both focus more on web services rather than just
corejson.json.net was and every time they were considerably more popular
yeah this was just a discussion what do you think about combining our libraries and my response to them is
you're completely welcome to take what i've done and reuse it and learn from it but i feel like i've achieved all i want
to achieve and i'm gonna go work on something else something else which interests me
and every time that is what open source felt to me i felt like you would put out
a blog post or maybe you'd write an article on co-project and then you'll be done and you go work on
something else so what changed why do i keep working on it so would you believe it was coplex
so i may have just made some old koplex project manager's day
so i made one final release of json.net two coplex and part of the reason i did that was
every time the source code was sort of hosted and visual source safe on my

and the zip file was like sitting in a sub directory underneath my
donate powered blog but what i didn't realize at the time
when i moved to koplex is i was suddenly getting all these new
features and ways of interacting with the community so suddenly i had discussions i had ways to um have people
come along and request new features and talk about how they were using json.net
issues for bugs um people could submit reviews and i could see statistics of how
downloads were growing and people were adopting it source code it was tfs
at the time i think the way you collaborated and submitted code was you'd go into coplex i mean like you
would download a zip file containing all source code and you unzip it you'd make some changes and you'd zip it back up
again and you upload it back to uh coplex then i would have to download
it and i'd have to unzip it then i'd have to like manually merge things it was it was awful but otherwise koplex was um it was all
right so without realizing it suddenly i had a community so i could talk with people i
could learn how they were using json.net what was easy what was hard and for me this was a motivation i think
i like programming challenges and i think this is true for most developers otherwise during our spare time we'd off
we'd go off and climb mountains and row kayaks and stuff but i prefer my programming challenges
to be practical rather than theoretical and seeing people practically use my library in the real world
and have issues with it i mean i'd like come up with a fix for it and suddenly the real world example was much better
and that was really motivating for me of course sometimes having a community
can be difficult you don't always agree um and
things can quickly escalate then if you do something that they don't like
but that's working with developers and it's better yeah it's
sometimes it's annoying but um for most part it's it's a great time
so since i started way back then just having source code on my blog and um
and downloading a link the ways of interacting with people and the open source community has
continued to grow and grow so i talked about it earlier there's
issues and on coplex and github nuget has really revolutionized the way
that open source developers and regular.net developers acquire open source and also you can see
on nuget comprehensive stats of how your library has been downloaded and
also you can see other libraries take dependencies on you which you wouldn't have seen before
you've got sites like tekkenpower who do benchmarks and in my case so taken power
is mainly focused on web benchmarks but in my case there's a blog called
burning monk which looks more at donate serialization it does benchmarks of different libraries
in that space and this has really pushed um open source developers to be better and
faster competing against each other being measured against each other like this um
gas and github and other distributed source control systems have obviously made um contributing and collaborating
much easier and finally twitter has really revolutionized
ways for people to come along and tell you that you're wrong and you're bad and you should feel bad
so two years after i first released jason.net um adoption really started to grow i was
getting a lot of downloads and with all those downloads i was also getting a lot of requests for help
what went from maybe one question a week had become maybe one or more a day
so here's a graph of json.net downloads from koplex over time and it's kind of interesting to look at it's got a really
weird shape unfortunately koplex didn't put years on that i don't think they expected people
to still be using it in 10 years
so we can see here back in november 2014 i mirrored downloads onto github
and as soon as i did that so most people started downloading things from github rather than coplex
although still quite a surprisingly large number of people do use coplex for downloads
we can see in january 2011
i first uploaded the package to nougat and after that
sort of downloads from coplex sort of started to level off as more people use nougat to acquire the library rather
than downloading the zip file you can see way back in march 2008 so
that's when i released json.net json.2 and although it looks kind of small at the time
when i released json.net 2 sort of downloads pretty much doubled which was i was very excited about that blip back
then it doesn't look so impressive now so i think as it was about 2008 2009 is
when i really started feeling overwhelmed and it wasn't just that people were
asking for help it was that they were asking for help not because of bugs in the library
or because of missing features the features were there that they needed it's just they didn't know about them
they didn't know how to use them so it was at that point i really started to put some effort into writing documentation
and the first thing i learned is xml documentation alone by itself isn't enough
so xml documentation that's the thing uh it's the text that you see when you use intellisense and also a lot of
websites like msdn you can um to build html from it and it sort of becomes the
api documentation now this
kind of xml documentation is useful maybe if you want to find out what an individual class or method does but it
really doesn't help developers solve high level problems so
if we use a metaphor of a coffee machine you can think of xml documentation kind
of like low-level descriptions of all the different parts of a coffee machine now if you're familiar with the coffee
machine you could probably use this sort of documentation to figure out how to make a cup of coffee or maybe you've
just got a lot of time and a lot of patience and you're happy to experiment
but what you really want as a user is you want a high level guide telling you how to achieve your goal you want a
cup of coffee here is the library the coffee machine to do it for you and here is how you use it
so the other kind of documentation i found was really useful is developers they love examples they just
want to see an example of their problem their exact problem being solved and then they want to copy it
so it's not the best way to improve as a developer but that's the way developers
apparently like to work so back in 2012 i had a long flight back
from a conference in europe so flying back from europe to new zealand it's about 35 to 40 hours
many flights a lot of layover and i was coming back from a conference and i was super energized to their
conference about open source so my goal in that 40-hour flight was to write 100 samples for jason.net
i did not give air i think i maybe got up to about 50.
but you you can see um sort of like a list of them down on the on the left hand side of that
that screenshot but this this one example alone this was
the most popular one um it gets thousands and thousands of views every month and all together those
um examples probably get over 100 000 views every month it's really quite remarkable
so another thing i learned for reducing support the amount of time you need to give
support is how your library fails is important so one of my passions is donate api
design so this is the only sort of time i'll jump into that in this talk
but you can think when you're using a library
even though i've just said documentation is really important users don't tend to read documentation
at first so if they encounter a problem they're going to try and solve it a little themselves and then
when they concede defeat they'll go off and look at stack overflow or google or documentation
so what you want is if a user fails you want to let them know why they
failed so ms code sample up here this is the most
common error people tend to have with json.net you've got a person which has hobbies
my hobbies is a collection but the user is trying to deserialize a string into that collection
which will work they don't they don't match up so the error i originally got
in the initial versions of jason.net is i'd tell them this
expected jason array contract got jason string contract that's using a lot of
low-level internal types it really doesn't help the user my user gets that and they were all very confused i used
to get tons and tons of support requests about that
and probably on stack overflow there are lots of questions um what's this error mean
so i started improving on it so this was v2 of that error message
area converting system string to type ilist string of string
and that certainly improved it it reduced the number of support requests and
but it was still was the the most common way uh was still the most common problem people were having with json.net so i
improved it some more so error converting the value then i'd tell them the value to the type
and then i give them a path to it i'm adjacent so that hobbies is represents
the hobbies um to the left of the string and then i'll give them the line number
and position and so once i got to that level of detail most developers could pretty
quickly figure out hey wait a second the hobbies that i was trying to serialize into that i list as
a string those don't match up
and if you compare it to the original error yeah it's really night and day when it comes to solving
solving your problem
so those are a couple of my tips on how you should give support how shouldn't you give support
so if someone asks for any help over any of these mediums i just i say no
and the reason i say no is because they simply don't scale when you answer a question you want to
answer it once and have it somewhere that is easily searchable and discoverable and have other
developers reuse your answer multiple times in the future so where should you give support
sec overflow john skeeter's nodding
so my reply to developers asking for help on github
is um i'll close their quest i'll close their issue and i'll say please repost
this on stack overflow because i use stack overflow for support now a great thing about stack overflow
is not only is it easy to search both via its own search and also via
google google rates stack overflow quite highly is there are also many many developers
on stack overflow eager to answer questions everyone loves stack overflow reputation so there's only one of you
there's probably like a dozen people interested in answering questions about jason.net or more on on stack overflow
so the screenshot here you can see is of the json.net tag so i recommend when you've
got an open source project encourage the usage of a tag and that way people can use that tag to quickly
find more help about json.net now you can see here there's about five well almost 6 000 questions about
json.net on stack overflow and some of those questions um over on
the left they've got hundreds of thousands of views if you're just one developer answering
each developer's questions one by one it's it's obviously completely impossible so i recommend
using stack overflow as a resource
so as well as making it easier for developers to help themselves and sort of scaling your support um to avoid
going insane you need to invest in making your own development easier
so one of the best things i ever did when working on jason.net is i took an
entire day um during during one weekend many years ago and i sat down and i learned powershell
i learned sake so sake is a sort of a build script
a build library for sake for powershell so similar to make and rake and cake
and i built a script that would build jason.net and admit the many versions of
jason.net so there's version adjacent on it for net 2 and 3.5 and 4 and 4.5
and silverlight and so on and so on
um it would build all those together into a nuget package it would build the documentation
it would run all the tests and tests for each one of those different libraries or package everything together in a zip
file and it would do that all with one click of a button and the timer invested in doing that is
probably repaid itself dozens of times over back again
so as well as um just being able to run that on my own local machine to verify that there aren't any issues in json.net
i've been able to take it and put it on a build server so in the screenshot here you can see is appvaya so appvay is a
net focused website that offers building a build server as a service
and i really recommend it it's super easy to get started and get going like you can literally create an account point it at
a uh at a github repo maybe a little bit of configuration to
tell it where the solution is and then this thing will just go off and i'll get you a sort content it'll download it
onto itself and it'll build your project it's really easy and it also has a free
option for open source projects
so for things i haven't automated i like to make checklists so this is my official real json.net
release checklist completely unchanged so i run through this checklist every time i release a new version of json.net
for most part it's automated but there are a couple of things i do manually in there and the
reason i find this useful is quite often with open source there's big periods of time in between releasing new versions
so sometimes it might be a week between jason.net releases because there's an urgent bug sometimes it might be six
months and having a checklist means i'm confident
that if i follow this checklist i'm going to put out a good release of jason.net i'm not going to break everyone because i forgot to strong name
or i forgot to increment the version number or i've got some file out of the nuget package
and yeah if i break json.net all hell will break loose
and finally the most important investment i think you can make in making development easier is unit tests
so unlike a commercial project you might be working on with lots of other developers
you there there is no test team there are no testers to double check that the release that you're about to put out to
the wild is good so you need unit tests to be able to
capture any mistakes you might make and also capture anything regressions you make and any breaking
changes you inadvertently make so i've put a lot of effort into
unit testing with json.net so you can see there there's about two and a half thousand unit tests in the
top left corner and also i quite like to use code coverage
so json.net has between 90 and 95 code coverage so that's hitting all the important paths and before i release a
new version of json.net quite often i'll run code coverage i mean i'll go look at
the feature i've just added and i'll just make sure there's a test hitting all the important lines before it goes
out into the wild so i think the the main takeaway i've
learned while working on json.net as it's just grown in such a huge scale is you do
need to take time to invest in making your own life easier when it comes to doing
development don't get too focused on solving the problem of a day that a user approaches
you with otherwise things just become completely unwieldy
and messy and horrible and it stops being fun to work on having a lot of unit tests that you can rely on means
i've been able to go into json.net and make some quite enormous changes to the
ways the internals work as i've learned and grown as a developer and if i didn't have all those unit tests i simply
wouldn't have the confidence to do that because i would introduce bugs without myself knowing
so now i want to talk about people
so dealing with people it's interesting so what i want to focus on here is how to
um maintain your enjoyment while still interacting with other developers
so focus on what what can you do to keep your mental health
so this is a this is a pretty funny tweet by a guy who used to work at github
and i think it's quite easy for it to become true and the reason i think it becomes true
is because of what you as an open source maintainer c of users who are adopting your library
so what you see as an open source maintainer is really just a tip of an ice work the main way
you see developers is via github issues and github issues are usually only when
people come to you when they've got a problem so there's bugs or there's features requests or there's
something that you haven't touched in so long or they want strong naming or they don't want strong naming
that being the main way that you interact with users and that you see users using your library can sort of
color your perception of like entire success or failure of your
library if everyone who's talking to me about jason.net is having problems
then i must be doing an awful job i must be horrible um i should just give up and stop
but what you realize is that sort of below the tip of the iceberg is there's
just this silent majority of developers using your library and getting stuff done like
they might still be having maybe an issue they don't know how to do something but they go to the documentation they fix it maybe they go
to stack overflow and they fix it but they've solved their problem and they're happy and they've moved on to something
else and those are the developers who don't really see
so the other thing i'd recommend with working with people is don't be afraid to say no so i've already mentioned that if people
come to me for help i just say um please direct questions to stack overflow and maybe if someone
doesn't answer your question maybe because it's quite difficult i'll look at it after maybe a week or so
and also say no to features that you don't want i think there's a lot of pressure
to merge every pull request or add every feature not all pull requests are good
not all features are good and i've had to do this quite a lot with json.net so for years people used to ask me to
make a web framework that expose json.net they'd say we hate wcf and we
hate the way it does json can you please turn json.net into a web web framework and i
said no because i knew if i started developing a web framework then i'd need to worry about
stuff like doing authorization and authentication and caching it would have
been an entirely new project by itself and i already had more than enough to work on with json.net so it's important
like you put a boundary around what you'd want to work on and then focus within that boundary
and yeah my reply to most of people who ask that was okay someone else can do it
and eventually someone did so microsoft then adopted json.net when they built
web api
so this is another another good tweet you can say no now and maybe reconsider
it in the future but as soon as you say yes you kind of need to support it forever so with jason on it i'm often quite
patient and if i get a feature request that i'm a little unsure about i
just think about it for a while maybe i'll say no maybe i'll say yes but yeah don't don't give in to the
pressure to merge every pull request and do every feature
and something i really recommend is guiding your contributors so
github supports this idea of a contributing markdown file
an ms file you can sort of give instructions about you can give instructions to
contributors or people creating new issues or pull requests um about how to contribute to your project so
um with the one i've written for json.net i sort of explain what information i need to be
able to reproduce your bug so i need um if you've got an issue serializing stuff
i need the json i need um the class i maybe need whatever settings you're using
if you want to submit a pull request i tell people could you please if it's a big pull
request mention a feature to me first because i don't want to reject all your changes that you've put
a lot of work into
so github once you've created this contributing markdown file um it's then visible
whenever someone creates a new issue or a new pull request so you can see up there please review the guidelines for
contributing to this repository so that's a link to that markdown file i just mentioned earlier
so finally i'll end with why open source why do all this work it seems like a lot of hassle and a lot of heartache
and i'll start off with a slightly controversial topic that will be of money

and that's some people's view of open source it's successful when it starts making money and of course this isn't
necessary but some open source projects do grow quite large and they're quite time
consuming for people who work on it and maintain it so i thought i'd just like give a couple
of moments into talking about money and my experiences um so has everyone watched
south park so south park has this episode about these gnomes that steal underpants
and they have this business plan so step one is steel underpants step two we're not quite sure yet step three profit
so in the context of open source i will tell you what step two is not
and it's not do nothing so if you've got a popular open source
project um that maybe some big fortune 500 company has started using and maybe
it saved that fortune 500 company maybe hundreds of developer hours
you probably shouldn't expect them to just come along out of nowhere and give you a check and say this is for all the
time you've saved us good work that's not that's that doesn't happen in my experience
so if that doesn't work um what can you do so one option is sponsorship so this is
what the um glimpse guys have uh or what they used to do with uh redgate
so redgate sponsored um uh nick and anthony to work on glimpse for a couple
of years uh i know nancy also exp uh had some

you can do commercial add-on so this is something i do and also hang fire so hang fire is like a

you can do commercial support and training and consulting and an example of a company

working on open source gives you the opportunity to work on and learn things you might never would have otherwise

either did for the first time or did for the only time while working on jason.net
you can see unit testing is up there jason.net was the very first time i ever did unit testing and if you

by hundreds or maybe thousands of developers around the world and they can get stuff done and
they can use your stuff and your stuff can solve problems

um when you go to a conference you quite often instantly have something
